awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds three research projects in game theory. The first analyzes strategic situations in which participants communicate freely, including making statements with no strategic motives. The second project seeks to develop new methods for determining which equilibrium results are consistent with specific concepts of consistency. The third project analyzes how a profit-maximizing multi-product monopolist will choose a marketing strategy when it has incomplete information about demand. The goal here is to develop bounds on the maximum possible sales, which could provide some insight into why such firms frequently bundle goods. The results of these projects may create new tools for analyzing bargaining, negotiation, and repeated market interactions.

The first project analyzes a model without the common explicit enumeration of all possible actions for the players; in practice this limits communication possibilities. Instead the PI develops a model in which players are able to freely announce their private information. Using a new refinement of sequential equilibrium, the resulting outcomes are often stable in the Kohlberg-Mertens (1986) sense. The second project presents an argument that normal form perfection, rather than backward induction or sequential equilibrium, captures the decision-theoretic consequences of dynamic consistency in games. The researcher then develops an equilibrium-based analog of rationalizability to address the issues of invariance. This means that invariance is sought as a result rather than being imposed as an axiom. The third project tackles a complicated problem in multi-dimensional optimal mechanism design. While there are no known methods for providing useful characterizations of the solution, in practice we observe that firms use simple mechanisms. The project will examine whether good revenue bounds can explain the wide use of these mechanisms.

por.por_cntn:
This project produced a total of 6 peer-reviewed publications and 2 working papers as follows.

1. A Simple Sufficient Condition for a Unique and Student-Efficient Stable Matching in the College Admissions Problem, 2021, Economic Theory Bulletin, 9, 7–9.

2. Nash Equilibrium in Discontinuous Games, 2020, Annual Review of Economics, 12, 439-470.

3. An Improved Bound for the Shapley–Folkman Theorem, with Eric Budish, 2020, Journal of Mathematical Economics, 89, 48–52.

4. Perfect Conditional ε-Equilibria of Multi-Stage Games with Infinite Sets of Signals and Actions, with Roger Myerson, 2020, Econometrica, 88, 495–531. Supplementary Material.

5. The Better Half of Selling Separately, with Sergiu Hart, 2019, ACM Transactions on Economics and Computation, 7, 4, Article 18.

6. Existence of Optimal Mechanisms in Principal-Agent Problems, with Ohad Kadan and Jeroen Swinkels, 2017 Econometrica, 85, 769–823

7. A Canonical Game -- 75 Years in the Making -- Showing the Equivalence of Matrix Games and Linear Programming, with Ben Brooks, July 17, 2021.

8. Efficient Matching in the School Choice Problem, January, 2021

 

All of this work is purely theoretical in nature, and much of the work is intended to support the success of economists build strategic models of greater generality, allowing for more robust applicability. Good examples of this work are the papers on existence of Nash equilibrium in discontinuous games and on perfect conditional ε-equilibria. These two papers can greatly extend the reach of applied theorists in the areas of auction theory, where virtually all games are discontinuous, as well as in dynamic game settings, such as arise in the theory of oligopoly, with many actions and complex information structures. Prior to the work completed in this project, one could not draw upon standard methodologies to study these important strategic situations.

Some of the work, e.g., the better half of selling separately, is cross-disciplinary in that it embraces ideas from computer science and applies them to questions of some importance to the economic theory of mechanism design, especially as relates to optimal selling mechanisms. In that work, we begin with the intractable problem of how a monopolist should optimal sell two goods to a population of consumers when the goods' use-values to consumers are unknown as, for example occurs when a cable services provider must decide how to price various bundles of programming. Although the general solution t this problem is unknown, we introduce techniques that allow us to place tight bounds on the revenue that can be earned when the monopolist simply charges the monopoly price for each good separately. Quite surprisingly, we are able to show that this simple pricing strategy guarantees the monopolist, under some natural conditions, at 73% of the revenue that it could obtain if charged the revenue maximizing prices (obtaining these, however, is an unsolved and generally intractable problem). We are hopeful that the techniques introduced in this paper can be helpful for future work that attempts to better understand the pricing strategies used by multi-product monopolists.

Also during the project period, we also began investigating the efficiency of school-choice matching algorithms. While it is well-known that these often leave many students worse off than they could have been, since rearranging some students after the match can place all of those students at schools they prefer, leaving other students' matches unchanged, finding a suitable solution has been an open question. Our preliminary work on this problem has been very promising. We believe that we have found a solution, i.e., mechanism for matching students to schools when schools have priorities and students submit their ranked lists of schools to the mechanism, that incentivizes students to report truthfully, so long as they are sufficiently unsure of the lists that other students will report and they are sufficiently averse to risk. Moreover, the matching that is produced will have the desirable property that no other matching can make any student better off without making any student worse off, and, the matching that is produced will be better for every student than the matching that would have arisen if the deferred acceptance matching mechanism (one in use throughout the country) were used instead. Thus, this new matching mechanism has the potential to help many thousands of students each year get placed at schools that they prefer.

Modified by: Philip J Reny
